journal-meta.journal-title: Journal of Reinforced Plastics and Composites

title-group.article-title: Acoustic emission wavelet transform on adhesively bonded single-lap joints of composite laminate during tensile test

article-meta.aff: 1Department of Production Technology, Madras Institute of Technology, Anna University, Chennai, India
2Department of Mechanical Engineering, Cauvery College of Engineering and Technology, Tiruchirapalli, India
3Department of Aerospace Engineering, Madras Institute of Technology, Anna University, Chennai, India

author-notes.corresp: K Mohamed Bak, Department of Production Technology, Madras Institute of Technology, Anna University, Chennai 600044, India. Email: mohamedaero@yahoo.com

permissions.copyright-statement: © The Author(s) 2013 Reprints and permissions: sagepub.co.uk/journalsPermissions.nav

abstract.p: Acoustic emission detection in composites is complicated in comparison with metallic structures due to the complex nature of acoustic emission wavelet transform in anisotropic materials. In this study, the adhesively bonded single-lap joints with zero-degree orientation are used to trigger different failure mechanisms when subjected to tensile test with acoustic emission monitoring. Acoustic emission signals which are studied for damage characterization are obtained during tensile tests. The range of peak frequency with time, pertaining to the failure mode in adhesively bonded single-lap joints has been identified using wavelet transform. Signals and their characteristics representing different failure modes are identified and validated using wavelet transform analysis. Continuous wavelet transform is then applied to identify the frequency range and time history for failure modes in each signal. The fractured surface area of the bonded single-lap joint specimen was examined directly using a scanning electron microscope and also identified the failure mechanism of bonded single-lap joints. The results obtained from acoustic emission technique are compared with scanning electron microscope results, to find the evidence of predicted damage. This study of the frequency content of each test using continuous wavelet transform is then performed and the classification of several failure modes is identified.

sec.title: Introduction
sec.p: Ideally, it is always preferred to make monolithic structures, that is, structures without joints. This ideal can never be realized for many reasons, such as size limitations imposed by materials or the manufacturing process, need for disassembly of structure for transportation, access for inspection and repair, etc. Basically, there are two types of load-carrying joints available: mechanically fastened joints and adhesively bonded joints. In aerospace and automobile applications, they are used for joining various composite parts together, and are fastened together either using adhesives or mechanical fasteners.1 Recently, it has become the primary method of testing fiber-reinforced plastics of aerospace structures. One of the key areas in composite structural design involves the joint strength. Adhesively bonded lap joints are most preferred, because they develop smooth load transfer and have fewer points of stress concentration when compared to fastened joints, where the failure prediction of such joints is extremely important since their failure might lead to catastrophic failure in aircraft during its service period.2,3 Many non-destructive testing (NDT) techniques are used to characterize the damage mechanism in composite materials. The acoustic emission (AE) technique is one of the NDT methods that analyze the characteristics of elastic waves that are caused by microscopic damage in the composite structure4 and it is also a real-time structural health monitoring under quasi-static loading and dynamic-cyclic loading.5 AE test is the test in which the stress waves are produced by the sudden internal stress redistribution of the materials caused by the changes in the internal structure. AE technique has been widely used in industries for the detection of faults or leakage in pressure vessels, metallic structures, and composite components. The possible causes of the internal structure changes are crack initiation and growth, crack opening and closure in monolithic materials and matrix cracking, fiber–matrix debonding, and fiber breakage in composite materials.6 Beatite et al.7 investigated that fatigue tests of large fiber-reinforced plastic (FRP) wind turbine blades can be monitored by AE techniques and they produce useful information. Huang et al.8 studied that accumulation of microdamage inside the structural components especially under service conditions using AE in fatigue and fracture materials. Liang et al. investigated that different processing techniques can be used depending upon the nature of AE signals. For monitoring manufacturing processes, the popular method of spectral analysis using fast Fourier transform (FFT) is used wherein the sensor signals are assumed as stationary. However, while processing non-stationary signals whose spectral character changes with time, they find difficulty in extracting characteristic features. These problems have been successfully eliminated by the introduction of wavelet transform (WT) which is a time–frequency distribution. It allows the evaluation of frequency spectrum as a function of time using short waveform segments or wavelet as the basis functions.9 Resultant mapping of wavelet coefficients in time–frequency coordinate plane provides more effective information; thus, wavelets can be an ideal tool for analyzing the failure modes of single-lap joints. Qi conducted tensile tests on uni-directional and cross-ply specimens with a central circular hole monitored using AE. AE activities were concentrated in the frequency range of 100–300 kHz. Discrete wavelet analysis was applied to decompose the AE signal into different wavelet levels (discrete wavelet decomposition), each of them representing a specific frequency range.10 In particular, Qi11 studied the fracture behavior of composite materials using wavelet-based signal processing. Prosser12 studied the damage mechanism of uni-directional graphite/epoxy composite such as matrix cracking can produce a wide range of AE signal parameters, by virtue of the simplicity of these parameters, there are often conflicts noticed due to factors such as attenuation and wave dispersion. Kamala et al.13 studied the frequency content of a signal which can be examined using frequency spectra obtained through use of the FFT or by examining its time–frequency evolution using either discrete or continuous WT analysis.

This study is to investigate the characteristics of failure modes and strength of adhesively bonded single-lap joints with zero-degree fiber orientation using AE WT analysis and scanning electron microscope (SEM). The mechanical properties and AE response in glass-FRP (GFRP) adhesively bonded lap joints are used as a basis to identify the AE waveforms pertaining to the failure modes. The sequence of failure events and their associated frequency content are studied by performing frequency on the signals. Time information along with frequency range for the different failure modes is obtained using the wavelet transformation technique. Among the time–frequency distributions, WT is relatively the latest technique in wavelet analysis, wherein resolution can be achieved both at low and high frequencies, thus adopted in this study.

sec.title: Classification of failure mode
sec.p: Adhesive, cohesive, and thin-layer cohesive failure are matrix failures. Fiber-tear and light-fiber-tear are the fiber failures.

sec.title: WT analysis of AE data
sec.p:
The WT of an energy-limited signal f(t) can be represented by its WT bases as (Daubechies15) (1)f(t)=1Cϕ∫-∞∞∫a>0∞FW(a,τ)1aϕ(t-τa)1a2dadτ where f represents the frequency, t the time shift or location, C a constant depending on the base function, and FW [a, τ] the WT which is defined as (2)FW(a,τ)=1a∫f(t)ϕ(t-τa)dt f(t)∈L2(R) Figure 1.
Different types of failure in composite to composite adhesive joints.

Equation (1) implies that the WTs can be considered to be signal decomposition. It decomposes a signal f(t) into a family of wavelet bases and coefficients. FW (a, τ) represents the amplitudes at given location τ and frequency a.

Depending on the wavelet function, there are various discrete WTs (DWTs) such as the binary WT and wavelet packet transform. In this study, the wavelet packet transform is used. The WT decomposes a signal into various components (packets Pji(t), where i is the packet number and j the number of levels), based on which the characteristic features of the signal can be captured. In the first resolution j = 1, the signal is decomposed into two packets: P11(t) and P12(t). The packet P11(t), represents the lower frequency component of the signal, while the packet P12(t) represents the higher frequency component of the signal. Then, at the second resolution j = 2, each packet is further decomposed into two sub-packets forming P21(t),P22(t),P23(t), and P24(t). This decomposition process continues and at each subsequent resolution, the number of packets doubles while the number of data points in the packet are reduced by half.

Mallat16 used DWT to discriminate AE signals by decomposing each signal into different continuous frequency bands which depend on the level of decomposition. WT is another technique used to characterize the failure modes. Yan and Yam17 studied the different failure modes using WT. The WT can decompose the AE signals in time and wavelet scale domains and catch the differences in these waves. Suzuki et al. studied that application of static fracture mechanisms to fatigue fracture behavior of glass A-SMC composite. The WT contains the information of the signal in different time windows at different ranges of resolution. Each packet corresponds to some frequency band. The WT that contains the characteristic features of the signal is referred to as feature packets.18–20 In general, the packets which have higher energy are called feature packets. In this study, the energy of WT is taken as criteria for the selection of feature packets. Based on the energy in each packet, feature packets are selected and energy in each packet is calculated as per equation (3) (3)Eji=Σi=1N [Pji(t)]2
From the WT of AE signals, it was observed that the AE activities were concentrating in the frequency range of 0–500 kHz.

sec.title: Specimen preparation
sec.p:
Composite laminates are fabricated by hand lay-up method and 300 × 300 mm2 GFRP composite laminate is fabricated with three layers of glass-fiber with epoxy as the binding medium. The symmetric ply [0°/0°]3 laminates were then cured by a compression molding machine at 100 kPa pressure and room temperature for 24 h. Aluminum tabs are used in the specimens to reduce the noise produced during testing. ASTM D5868-01 standard tensile specimens of size 100 × 25.4 × 3 mm3 were cut using water-jet cutting to avoid machining defects and to maintain good surface finish from the fabricated laminates as shown in Figure 2.21 The adherent surfaces cleaned with acetone were bonded for single-lap joint specimen. Figure 2.
(a) Adhesive thickness of 0.4 mm (1 and 3 - adherends, 2 - adhesive area) and (b) ASTM 5868-01 adhesively bonded lap joint specimen with thickness of 0.4 mm.

sec.title: Tensile test
sec.p: The specimens were subjected to uni-axial tension until they failed in 30 kN INSTRON 3367 universal testing machine (UTM) under AE monitoring using eight-channel AE shown in Figure 3. The specimens were mounted on the UTM machine and dimension of the specimens were entered into the software. The crosshead speed was maintained at a rate of 0.15 mm/min. Matrix failure and damages in the specimens during the conduct of tensile test were monitored.

sec.title: AE monitoring setup
sec.p:
An eight-channel AE setup supplied by Physical Acoustics Corporation (PAC) is used for AE studies, as shown in Figure 3. AE activities were sensed using a wide band WD piezoelectric sensor, filtering out frequencies exceeding 900 kHz and noise was filtered using a threshold at value of 45 dB. High-vacuum silicone grease was used as a couplant. The amplitude distribution covers the range of 0–100 dB. After mounting two transducers on the specimen at a mutual distance of 126 mm between them, they were both at the same distance from the center of the specimen length; a pencil Figure 3.
INSTRON 3367 UTM with AE set.
AE: acoustic emission; UTM: universal testing machine.
lead break procedure was used to generate repeatable AE signals for the calibration of each sensor, as shown in Figure 4. AE wave velocity for the specimen was found to be 3,278,642 mm/s. Continuous wavelet analysis is initially used to track and identify the different Figure 4.
Calibration of sensors and random location test.
Figure 5.
Load vs displacement curve of bonded lap joints for adhesive thickness of 0.4 mm.
Table 1.
Ultimate load and displacement of bonded lap joints for adhesive thickness of 0.4 mm
S. No Over lap thickness (mm) Load (kN) Displacement (mm) Average load (kN) Average displacement (mm)
Specimen 1 Specimen 2 Specimen 3 Specimen 1 Specimen 2 Specimen 3
1 0.4 6.0 5.8 6.0 1.58 1.35 1.6 5.93 1.51
failure mechanisms based on the AE WT analysis for bonded single-lap joint specimen.

sec.title: Load vs displacement for bonded single-lap joints
sec.p:
The average ultimate loads and displacements of bonded lap joints with adhesive thickness of 0.4 mm were found to be 5.93 kN and 1.51 mm, respectively, as shown in Figure 5. The ultimate failure load and elongation of the each specimen are tabulated in Table 1. After the tests were completed, the specimen displacements, failure loads, and mechanical behavior were recorded in SAMOS E3.10 data acquisition system of PAC using UTM. At the bonded thickness of 0.4 mm, most of the specimens failed by adhesive failure and light-fiber failure, as shown in Figure 6. In bonded joints, the stress was distributed throughout the laminate and the adhesive takes up much of the load. Here, the load transfer between the substrates took place through a distribution of shear stresses in the adhesive. Figure 6.
Adhesive and light-fiber failure observed on the overlap area.
Table 2.
Possible failure modes in adhesive joints using AE energy
Parameters/ failure mode Matrix failure Thin-layer adhesive failure Fiber-tear failure Fiber failure
Peak frequency (kHz) 80–130 130–220 220–290 Above 300
AE: acoustic emission.

sec.title: WT analysis of AE data
sec.p: AE technique was utilized in tracking the damage accumulation profile during tensile loading up to failure in terms of AE energy and peak frequency. The damage signals were identified by the sequence of frequency range in the failure process. Each damage generates an AE energy signal which is related to the amount of strain energy released during initial failure. Figure 7 shows AE energy vs peak frequency for different failure modes. It is apparent that adhesive failure signals in the frequency range between 80 and 130 kHz occurs at all energy levels. Thin-layer adhesive failure signals between 130 and 220 kHz have low energy, while Fiber-tear failure signals between 220 and 290 kHz possess medium energy and fiber failure signals associated with high-frequency content in the range above 300 kHz are found with very low energy. Table 2 represents possible failure modes in adhesive single-lap joints using AE energy.

As AE signals are not stationary, their significance is better understood by a wavelet analysis. The WT can decompose the AE signals in time and frequency domains and observes the differences in these waves. Typical time–frequency mapping of wavelet coefficients of the AE signals is monitored for adhesively bonded single-lap joints. Continuous WT (CWT) is allowed to identify frequency range and time history for failure modes in each signal while noise content associated with the different failure modes was identified by DWT.22–24 The test signals pertaining to the failure modes are always accumulated with random noise at Figure 7.
AE energy vs peak frequency.
AE: acoustic emission.
all instant of times during loading. Daubechies wavelets are used in which one can make use of the time and frequency domain information of the signals for classifying them.

Time information with frequency range of different failure modes are investigated using a CWT technique. Figure 8(a) to (d) shows the CWT representation of the failure modes such as matrix failure, fiber–matrix (thin-layer matrix) failure, fiber-tear failure, and fiber failure. The time–frequency representation obtained shows the high-energy areas which are used to identify the failure mechanisms. At initial stages of loading, low and medium frequencies are dominant which are related to matrix failure and fiber–matrix failure, respectively. With further increase in loading, high-frequency signal event occurs which is related to fiber-tear failure and fiber failure. Matrix failure signals are mainly in the frequency range of 80–130 kHz with low to medium duration and its wavelet coefficient corresponds to a value of 0.12. The AE signals due to matrix failure are dominantly composed of lower frequency, as shown in Figure 8(a). Fiber–matrix (thin-layer matrix) failure signals are mainly in the range of 130–220 kHz and its wavelet coefficient value Figure 8.
CWT representation of the different failure modes and SEM images of failure modes during tensile test: (a) matrix (adhesive) failure signal; (b) thin-layer matrix failure signal; (c) fiber-tear failure; and (d) fiber failure signal.
CWT: continuous wavelet transform; SEM: scanning electron microscope.
corresponds to 0.3 with medium duration. AE signals induced by the generation of fiber–matrix failure can be observed by examining the medium frequency range, as shown in Figure 8(b). Fiber-tear failure signals are mainly in the range of 220–300 kHz with high duration and its wavelet coefficient value corresponds to 1.6. The dominant frequency ranges of AE signals due to fiber-tear failure are moderate frequency bands, as shown in Figure 8(c). The fiber-tear failure which is occurring within the FRP substrate, near the surface, is characterized by a thin layer of the FRP resin matrix visible on the adhesive. Fiber failure signals are mainly in the range above 300 kHz with medium duration and higher value of wavelet coefficient of 2, when compared to the other failure modes. It can be seen by the presence of wavelet coefficients at higher frequency bands as shown in Figure 8(d). From the above results, it is observed that time–frequency representation highlights qualitative differences between signals and hence, it can be used as a better tool for the discrimination of failure modes in composite laminates.

SEM was performed on the failure surfaces to characterize and to classify various failure mechanisms with focus on damage, such as matrix failure, fiber–matrix failure, fiber-tear failure, and fiber failure, as shown in Figure 8(a) to (d). SEM examination of specimen subjected to a tensile test indicated that strong orthotropic properties were resulted in the formation of failure mechanism. Figure 8 shows the microstructure of the specimen which has been taken at low feed rate of 50 mm/min. The surface of the microstructure indicated that damage modes are observed for adhesively bonded single-lap joint specimen. Based on the microscopy analysis of damage, an approach using AE waveform parameter as damage mechanism was identified. The time information with frequency range of failure modes are studied using a WT technique.

sec.title: Conclusion
sec.p:
From the wavelet analysis of AE data during tensile test, the following conclusions can be drawn:
The ultimate load and displacement of each specimen were found during tensile testing.
The AE signal processing procedure was permitted successfully to identify the damage mechanisms based on the AE wavelet analysis technique. Time information with frequency range for specific failure modes, such as matrix failure, fiber–matrix failure, fiber-tear failure, and fiber failure were obtained.
A steady wavelet coefficient value of AE signals are observed using time vs frequency. The time information with frequency range obtained shows the high-energy areas which are used to identify the failure mechanisms.
The fractured surface of the microstructure indicated that damage modes were observed for composite bonded joint specimen using SEM.
The wavelet coefficient in CWT also serves a good technique to sub-classify the failure modes. The predominance of failure modes in each signal is used as a key in the study of discrimination of failure modes in composite laminates.

sec.title: Funding
sec.p: This research received no specific grant from any funding agency in the public, commercial, or not-for-profit sectors.
